Poppy the 3D Printed Robot

This is an opensource project that deserves to be shared and recognized on Thingiverse. It was on Thingiverse before, but later deleted by the user. This upload is to help raise awareness about this awesome project.

The source material came from: https://www.poppy-project.org/creatures/poppy-humanoid/

More information located at: http://www.gizmag.com/poppy-3d-printed-humanoid-robot-kit/29497/

My research into this project estimates that you can have your own 3D printed humanoid robot for approximately $8000 in hardware.

Poppy project notes

If interested in this project, the "Poppy_3D_Parts_Bundle.zip" contains all the 3D printable parts and they are organized by body section.

The STL files were uploaded so people could see the parts in the Thingiviewer without downloading them.

The source files have not changed in a while, but if you want to build this thing and run into trouble, visit the source of the project and various poppy forums for support.

Enjoy!

I have my filament spool mounted above and behind the machine so the filament can be easily fed into the extruder, however there was one problem, the filament would rub against the 8mm threaded rod when the extruder head (x-axis) moved back and forth.
So I thought, why not use a left over piece of 8mm smooth bar to fix it.
And to easily mount this I needed some quick snap in brackets, so here they are!

Print out a LEFT and a RIGHT Mendel Filament Guide bracket.
Cut a piece of 8mm smooth bar to the right length (approximately 30cm) and place the brackets on the left and right hand side respectively. The filament should run OVER the bar so put the bar between the filament and the filament spool and then hook the ends into the front top bar and snap onto the back top bar.

title: Apple Mighty Mouse Replacement Bottom Ring

description.text:
It is difficult to clean the Apple Mighty Mouse's mouse-ball without breaking off the bottom ring, which is both tabbed and glued on to the mouse.

This replacement friction fits in place. Start in the front and secure it around the sides to the back. It may require a little bit of sanding or shaving. There are 'gripping' holes near the rear, but I had to sand them a little. I'm not convinced they're doing any gripping.

Bonus: customize your Apple mouse with colors!

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4fq2bL2t0fH

Printed at 0.3mm layer height, 120mm/sec, on Replicator 1. Worked pretty well without much finishing.

Watch your layer height. 0.4mm left the front end weak at the wire cut-out. That area will need some tenderness when sanding.

remixed_from.author: ZygmuntW
remixed_from.title: Modular Support (Case) for Arduino and Raspberry Pi - CustoBlocks

description.text:
First of all I want to say thanks Gael Langevin who is the creator of the InMoov 3D-printed robot that I'm building.
You can find the original design on his site http://www.inmoov.fr.
This post is the second one in a series of changes that I have made to the head of the InMoov robot.
The first post can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:992918
The third post can be fond here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1035688
This post shows the parts that are used to mount the raspberry PI 2, the Arduino Uno, the USB soundcard and the servos for the eyes.
The holder for the Raspberry PI 2 is made from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:754078
The holder for the Arduino UNO is a remix to make more room for the USB cable.
The two holders are mounted back to back so that the Raspberry PI sits with the component side down and the Arduino with the component side up.
The USB Sound card is monted on bracket on the opposite side from the HDMI port of the Raspberry, as can be seen on the pictures.

If you want to use the parts from this post in the InMoov head, you first need to make the changes from my first post.

Print the holder for the Raspberry PI from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:754078 ( raspberrry_bPlus_2b.stl )
and the holder for the Ardino from here ( ArduinoUnoV2.stl).
Mount them back to back with screws. Make sure that the USB ports of the Raspberry and the Arduino will point in the same direction, i.e towards the back of the head.
Mount the Raspberry and the Arduino to the holder unit.
Print two brackets ( CardHolderV1.stl ). They don't have any monting holes at the bottom, so you have to drill them.
The big sqare hole in the brackets can be used to mount up to 4 servos on each side.
For example if you want to do facial expressions.
I mounted 3. One to tilt the eyes up and down.
One for each eye to turn left / right.
Print the USB Soundcard holder ( SoundCardHolderV1 ) if you plan to use a microphone. Mount the USB soundcard on the side of bracket as seen on the pictures.
The brackets can now be mounted to the Raspberry / Arduino. Mount the cables that you will use and test where it will fit best in the head.
Mark and drill holes in the brackets on the NeckRedesignV5 and screw it together with screws and nuts.

Experiences using the PI in the InMoov head

The PI runs the MyRobotlab software and communicates with the Arduino. I have tested using the camera from MRL and have had mixed results. My first test were OK, 16 fps, but then reinstalled Jessie and have not been able to get the same results. I think the problem is that I'm using OpenJDK at this moment. I will install Oracle java instead. You can see my first tests here: http://myrobotlab.org/content/opencv-300-and-javacv11-built-and-worky-raspberry-2. Update: Installing Oracle JDK made a huge difference. Not only for the performance of OpenCV but for all processes in MRL.

I also tested streaming from the PI camera to my PC. You can see the results here. http://myrobotlab.org/content/testing-streaming-rpi-camera-mplayer-my-pc

I tested doing some image processing in python (i.e outside MRL, since MRL is using jython). I found some good documentation on picamera https://picamera.readthedocs.org/en/release-1.10/ and I also read Adrian Rosebrocks blog and have tested many of his examples. http://www.pyimagesearch.com/ I have tested several image processing algorithms, but I'm still learning. And I have to admit that a lot of time has been spent on installing and compiling different components and dependencies to be able to do image processing.

Sound is a different chapter with it's own challenges. I can get sound from the USB soundcard, but I have trouble with startx overwriting my soundcard settings. Perhaps I can use MRL in headless mode to avoid that issue, but I haven't done that yet, since I use the web-browser to download much software for image processing.
I have spent many hours building the body for InMoov and I'm almost finished with the body. I received 8 new servos this week for the body, in addition to the 4 that I already have. I hope that I can make more progress during the holidays.
If you choose to use the PI, it's a more challenging task than to use a PC. But I don't regret the choise. I have learned many new things and that is the whole point for me. I don't have a clue how I will use the robot when it's finished, but I expect to learn many new things during the journey. And it's also a project where I can use the skills that learned in school, but never used.

description.text: VASE

I needed a more efficient filament cooling solution when printing PLA in my ZYYX 3D printer and so i decided to switch to a centrifugal fan.
Designing the duct was not an easy task, very limited space all the way down thru the extruder carriage and further down to the hotend/nozzle thus the slightly awkward and not the most efficient design. If the duct comes to close to the build plate use an exacto knife to carefully shorten it at the bottom.
The duct should lock into place securely as should the fan when mounted.
It´s important to note that even though the MB has a 24V output ZYYX uses a 12V fan. So if your going to use a 12V version of the new fan your all good but if your going witht the 24V version you need to remove the resistors (see picture) to get the most out of you new fan! Links to both the 12V and 24V version fans can be found below.

Centrifugal Fan, 24V: http://www.ebmpapst.com/en/products/compact-fans/radial-compact-fans/radial_compact_fans_detail.php?pID=54119
Centrifugal Fan, 12V: http://www.ebmpapst.com/en/products/compact-fans/radial-compact-fans/radial_compact_fans_detail.php?pID=54117

description.text: vase

This is a universal spool holder initially designed for the K8400 printer, but should work for a number of other models as well.

The idea is to fast and easy be able to change from all kinds of spool sizes. 19 and 60mm center hole adapters are included in the stl files. It´s capable to handel spools from 8mm and up...

I will add more spool holders in different sizes as i make/need them.

//J

Besides the printed parts you will need the following:
1pcs 8mm threaded rod (i used a 150mm)
4pcs M8 nut
2pcs 608 ball bearings
2pcs M8 washers

For mounting:
4pcs M5x25mm bolts (or the length you need)
4pcs M5 locking nut

Assembly instructions:
Just push the ball bearings in the printed parts, use 2 of the M8 nuts and adjust them to stop the rod from moving back and forth in the mount. I have about 1mm of wiggle room. Use another on the outside to stop the spool holder from hitting the mount, and the last one to lock the holder in place. I use washers between the nuts and the holder.

The stl to the holder is half so you need to print 2pcs.

Hope you like it!!

//J

author: raysand

description.text:
After 16 iterations, and inspired by a Bruce Sterling story (Kiosk), I've designed and printed a working hair clip. Length: 8.4cm
Height: 2.2cm
Depth: 1.2cm
Weight: 7g Printed in ABS, and utterly dependent on its mechanical properties, it features a working ABS hinge, three kinds of springs, and a snap fastener. This version is plain - the Sketchup file is included for those who want to go on and adorn their hair clips. Failing that, you can use the gently curved outer surface as a base for gluing on your own additions. Versions:
hairclip-mk15 = This version has four embossed stars on the outer bar (as seen in blue in the photograph).
hairclip-mk16-final = The flat backed version, easier to modify on your own. (Personal blog post regarding the Bruce Sterling story and other influences, here -
http://myriadwhimsies.wordpress.com/2011/07/11/jovanicas-hair-toys-3d-printed-hair-clips/)

Print in your favorite PLA/ABS colo(u)r.
The print takes approx 40 minutes on my Thingomatic, and requires a little bit of clean up with a sharp knife for stray whispy filaments.
Raftless seems to work better with this layout - the raft just takes longer to remove, adds more whispy filament ABS hairs to remove, and makes the print time longer.  No advantage.
<small >(The striped hairclip (blue and red) was achieved by feeding in different colo(u)red filaments during the printing process.)</small>

title: SPANNERHANDS Spool System Wall Mounted Spool Holder & Dust Cover

description.text:
V_2.0 Now Available
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2119644

Designed in Free Cad

Design Considerations:
Completely 3D Printable.
Fits most standard 200mm spools.
All parts can be printed without the use of supports.
Can be printed on printers with small build volumes.
Combo mount can be used as a wall mount or desk stand.
Clamping system mount option to attach it to anything.

UPDATE:
09/04/2017
Added Spool Core 50mm file, for spools with smaller internal diameters.
19/09/2015
Added a clamping system so you can attach the spool holder to a desk, shelf or aluminium extrusion etc...

Please see Instructions for more information...

I will be adding more parts and mounting options, open to suggestions & requests : - )

Minimum Configuration:
2 X SS Threaded Bolt V_1
2 X SS Segment Locking Ring V_1
2 X SS Segment Clip V_1
1 X SS Threaded Shaft V_1
1 X SS Segment with Mount V_1
1 X SS Combo Mount V_1

Spool System Clamp General Configuration:
1 X SS_Clamp_V_1
1 X SS_Clamp_Bolt_V_1
Optional:
1 X SS_Clamp_5mm_Shim_A_V_1
1 X SS_Clamp_5mm_Shim_B_V_1

Spool System Clamp for Aluminium Extrusions 20mm x 20mm:
1 X SS_Clamp_V_1
1 X SS_Clamp_Bolt_V_1
1 X SS_Clamp_AE_Shim_A_V_1
1 X SS_Clamp_AE_Shim_B_V_1

Printer Settings:

This design is more optimized for a 0.4mm Nozzle size.
For printing the segments & threaded parts I would recommend a maximum layer hight of 0.2mm, as that will help the overhang and especially the threaded areas of the parts print correctly.

title: Laser Cut Robot Kit - based off Pee Wee Rover

description.text:
Based off the Pee Wee rover kit, I designed a similar kit (the sizing is a bit different) with servo mounts, should you decide you want to add more functionality then just a robot that drives around.

I got the idea after we gave peewee kits out at the HeatSync Labs Nodebots Day event!

Using the Johnny-Five plugin for Octoblu you can build one that connects to the web easily using a standard arduino.

Just like this https://vine.co/v/eX9J2QpIZjH

Look for a tutorial on hackster.io/octoblu to come soon on how to connect this to the web.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DNmjuJAWO00

You'll need:

  • Motors : http://www.amazon.com/DIYmall-DC3-6V-Uniaxial-Magnetic-Gearbox/dp/B012FYMW54/ref=sr_1_17?ie=UTF8&qid=1441147167&sr=8-17-spons&keywords=geared+plastic+motors+with+wheel

  • Arduino Uno style board that support Firmata firmware

  • Polulu Motor Driver https://www.pololu.com/product/2511

  • Battery Pack

Then do this...

1 - Octoblu: app.octoblu.com

2 - Install Firmata to your Arduino and plug it into the computer running your Gateblu

4 - Install Johnny-Five plugin from app.octoblu.com

5 - Configure your board from the device details page.

6 - Build a flow to control it.

title: Universal wall spool holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
***Thing in progress!! thinghs might be improved or changed!!
This is my design of what I think is the most universal spool holder.

It is basically a support where you can insert any piece of rod, pipe, tube or wood stick of any lenght. It is made to fit a 30mm rod or smaller (about 1.2 inches).

There are two types so you can place it where you want; betwen two walls one infront the other (print "3cm perpendicular wall") in a 90 degree angle (print one of each) or on one single wall (print "3cm parallel to wall" one normal and one mirrored)

If you need to place the right part of the "3cm parallel to wal"

Depending on the infill of the printed parts, the lenght of the rod, the assemble to the wall and the type of rod the strenght of the spool holder will change.
When more infill, less lenght, stronger assemble and a more resistent rod (like a pvc tube or a solid wood stick) better will be the results. The opposite will be worse.

Mirror the "3cm parallel wall" if you want to print the right part of it.

Mine is printed with 100% infill and it is a 1 meter bamboo stick. It is assembled to the wall with 4.0 x 40 mm screws.

title: Easier printing top plate for LC100-A case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The original case design has a top plate that's difficult to print without supports.

I sliced the top into two pieces and flipped them on their back to allow for clean, supportless printing. Because of how the top plate joins into the bottom half of the case, as well as the LCD plate being screwed down, all the pieces neatly and securely are held in place asis without any gluing or such needed.

I used TinkerCad for the remixing. Links to the designs are here:

TinkerCad: LC100-A - Switch Plate

TinkerCad: LC100-A - LCD Cover

License is chosen to match the original designer's.

author: dgoodwin

title: Top Panel for Lulzbot Mini Enclosure

description.text: This thing is an Acrylic panel for enclosing the top of the Lulzbot Mini 3D Printer. We've had a number of requests to add a top panel for our enclosure kit. (available at: http://drazzticaction.com/products-page-2/3dprinters/lulzbot-acrylic-enclosure/ ) In limited testing we're seen approximately a 10 degree F increase in the build space, with this top plate installed (vs the rest of the enclosure installed - four sides, and leaving the top open). We'd recommend monitoring the build envelope temperature (we used an inexpensive meat thermometer), and not doing unattended printing, when the printer is buttoned up like this. Additional advantages with this top plate installed are that it keeps the interior dust free, and keeps things from falling into the printer. This panel attaches with the same lasercut panel clips as the rest of the enclosure, so it is easy to install and remove. We've made the top plate an option available at: http://drazzticaction.com/products-page-2/3dprinters/top-panel-for-lulzbot-mini-3d-printer/
Lasercut or rout out the profile from 3mm acrylic. Lasercut the clips from 6mm acrylic. Install per instruction for the other enclosure panels.

comments.author: Elidude

description.text:
This is a small piece to mount a neon lamp.
It's a replacement for the original mounting clamps which were way to weak to hold the lamp. Just for fun, I also produced a little documentation movie for this: "Better Living with MakerBot"
See: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LBzyZSVK_Gs Although the size of the clamp is probably very specific to the lamp I mounted, it should be quite simple to adjust the object for your needs. I included the model as OBJ-File (Wavefront), which can be opened with Blender and AOI.

description.text: Like many people, I had a stack of hard drive platters piling up. Each one is a highly polished aluminum mirror. I thought that there must be a 3D printed use for them. So I fired up 123D Design and made 2 different drink coaster/display bases. One based on a cylinder, with straight walls, and the other based on a torus, with curved walls.

Liberate a few hard drive platters from some obsolete or defective 3.5 inch hard drives. You'll need some very small Torx bits. Look under the labels for hidden screws.

All the platters seem to be the same 95mm in diameter. Some are slightly thicker than others but that doesn't matter here. The 2 designs should allow the platter to snap in place with a small bit of room for printer variations. If you find them too tight or loose, play with the X and Y dimensions in your slicer a bit. Multiply by 1.005 and see where that takes it.

If using for a drink coaster, I'd recommend spreading a small layer of silicone around the edges of the interior before you put the platter in place. Leave the center of the base clear of silicone so it doesn't show.That should keep liquid from migrating under the platter.

I started out printing them all black, then experimented with changing the filament color about halfway through the print. At .3mm layer height, there were 22 layers, so I changed at layer 11 or 12.

I printed them with .3mm layer height in PLA at 50mm speed with 15% infill.

The 123D Design files are included if you want to change anything.

title: FCU, PDB and ESC's mount plate

description.text:
I designed this to be modular and easy to remove as one assembly. Make sure you print this in ABS or Nylon, If you use Nylon it will be very flexible and easier to install and remove. the ESC's will melt PLA I am including the sketchup file for easy modification. If you make improvements please post the remix. These are the components I am using for this mount plate.

Mount the PDB with built in BEC first. Remove the heat shrink from the ESC's and snap into the holders. Solder all your leads to the PDB then install the FCU. Use two M3 6mm screws to secure the board to the bay for easy removal for upgrades and maintenance.

I have a google + forum called Robotic Drones that is for sharing ideas for drone technology.

version 2 update include longer posts, thinner FCU platform and mounting holes.

This thing is designed using OOML ( http://iearobotics.com/oomlwiki ). If you want to print it just download and print the STL. If you want to modify it install the OOML (instructions on the wiki) and compile using cmake or your favorite build tool Source code of this and other things can be found in http://github.com/avalero/3dthings
This is a heart-shaped drain plug for igloo cooler. Will fit other coolers.

These shoe hangers, inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:692969, can be used to hang shoes out of the way and in placed that normally would just be wasted space.

The version this was inspired by seemed to be too weak for my clod-hoppers (Size US13/EU45) sized shoes, and would break too easily.

So, I incorporated super-cheap bolts and nuts instead, leading to a much sturdier design.

Each hanger requires...

1 - 1/4" x 1 1/2" Course Threaded Hex Bolt
2 - 1/4" Course Threaded Hex Nuts

Seating the nut and bolt is easiest by just using the corresponding nut or bolt to pressure seat them by tightening them, pulling the nut head into the seating.

description.text:
WIP
Updated:

  • I printed all the parts with ABS, painted the red ones and tested up with only 2 LEDs.
    "Because i have lost the last one. :D"

  • Everything can be glued together without problems and the leds fit in the holes as well.

The only problem is with the vase that cracked on the borders, so i will rework the it using a circular form instead of a square one.

comments.text: So, I've gotten all of the parts printed except the caps. It is coming out very well (printing at 150% size). I had to use Netffab Basic to turn the parts correctly so that they would print. Other than that the only problem so far has been that the stems for the mushrooms seem to not be exactly on the same level. I managed to make it ok (it was extruding a full circle for each stalk only after the third layer) with super glue on the heated bed (Gorilla Glue brand manages to scrape off great and doesn't ruin my bed) and the parts stick fine.

Best enclosure on the market.

Enjoy better prints.

This was designed as a stand alone spool holder / case combination. When each spool is not in use, the central hub collapses on itself and can be closed off to prevent dust and moisture exposure. There is enough room at the bottom for adding desiccant packets to remove moisture (if needed).

NO EXTRA SUPPORTS NEEDED TO PRINT.

Once printed, gently twist center post of part #1 to break integrated supports. Then pull out to be fit to the keyed part #2. Spools can be easily changed out by separating parts through the keyhole.

Can support Makerbot filament and other spools up to 21cm in diameter (Central hub down to 30mm in diameter) and up to 11.5cm in width. The central hub for this design is 28mm in diameter and a simple adapter can easily make it accommodate larger hub sizes.

UPDATE: Added Makerbot Spool adapter. Mini adapter is thin enough to not consume a lot of filament. Print two and insert into both sides of spool.

UPDATE 9/4/2015: Split the parts for printing on smaller bed size. Each part (now subdivided into 'a' and 'b') is still printable without additional supports. Both 'a' pieces have break away supports where they overlap with the 'b' parts. The largest part is 147mm x 233mm x 120mm.

FilamentChallenge

Two files to print. No additional support needed. Gently twist central piece of part #1 to break integrated supports. Then fit keyed parts together.

Spools can be easily changed out by separating parts through the keyhole.

The palm of the fabulous Flexy-Hand 2 remodelled in t-splines. Use this if you wish to remix the Flexy-Hand but prefer to work in a nurbs / surface modeller.

The t-spline mesh (.tsm) can be opened in Fusion 360's sculpt desk, and in Rhino and Solidworks with the t-splines plugin. The STEP file can be opened in any surface / nurbs modeller. I have also provided the native Rhino (.3dm) file which contains a bunch of other stuff.

2015-09-01
Please note that this is a work in progress and does not yet contain any of the necessary features to make a working hand. I will update the files and these notes as further work is completed.

title: PrintRite DIY 3D Printer Improved Y-Axis Gantry End Blocks

description.text:
Replacement Y Axis Gantry End Pieces for the PrintRite DIY 3d Printer. The originals are really bad quality plastic without enough support. The Y Gantry would rock back and forth when the Z axis moved up and down. I added a place to mount some SCS8UU bearing blocks for additional stiffnes.. I mounted one, and it stiffened the whole thing up quite nicely.

In the gallery photos, the one on the left side of the printer is an earlier revision which had squared corners.

"Ballooningrich" has made a great addition to this part - an improved Z-Axis limit switch adjustment screw. You can find it at http://thingiverse.com/thing:1362486 Thanks, Rich!

Also see my fan duct design (3rd fan duct design I've done for this printer) : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1242620

I printed it with PETG at .2 mm thickness. Dimensions worked well. There are some bridged supports under the top of the stop collar over the side mounted bearing slots that have to be cut away after printing.

I decided to turn up the stepper motor current for the Z-axis a little bit after installing these blocks with the little potentiometer next to the Z-Axis stepper controller to prevent skipping. This caused the stepper controller chip to run a bit hotter than I was comfortable leaving enclosed in the case, so I added a 45mm fan on the controller case cover. Seems good. Have run > 20 hours since without any issues.

I also added a heated bed and workpiece fan to my printer.

comments.author: Manhattan004

comments.text: The motors were skipping steps due to the extra load on them due to friction from the additional bearing(s).  The current can be adjusted with the little potentiometers on the control board near the stepper controller chips.  They are under small heatsinks near each of the stepper connectors on the board.   If you do experience skipping or stalling of the motors, make very small adjustments of the skipping/stalling motor until you get the desired results.  Be aware that especially on the Z-Axis, the chip can get very hot if you turn it up too high and can fail or go into thermal shutdown.

description.text: A buddy of mine wanted me to make this for him, so I'm sharing here. Printing in Purple ABS.
Print upside-down so you don't need support.

Specialized wire antennas frequently require mounting hardware in various configurations to provide mechanical stability.  This is a collection of parametric parts designed to assist with constructing various wire antennas.
All of these models are parametric and should be easily adjustable to fit your needs.

Parts included are:
feedpoint -- perfect for mounting the feedpoint of a moxon, loop, or quad antenna on a fiberglass spreader.  The hole is tapered to fit common fiberglass rods that can be found in home improvement and hardware stores.  Adjust the screw hole size to fit whatever screws you have.
adjustable spacer -- print two of these and fasten together with a non-conductive screw, and attach wire ends with ring terminals.  This can be used when the antenna needs wire ends held at a specific distance apart, for example, as spacers in a moxon antenna.  Adjust slotlen to a bit more than half the length you need (remember, there's two of them) and to allow for adjustment; adjust slotw and holer for your screw sizes.  The teeth may need to be cleaned with a hobby knife and/or triangular file for best grip.
spreader -- use this to hold wires apart to make your own open wire transmission line.  Note that these are not calibrated for any particular impedance, and are designed to snap tightly on to some random wire I found. Adjust wired (wire diameter) and spread to suit your needs.  I made this part thin to minimize build time (I need a lot of them), but if you think it is too flimsy, adjust wall for a more stable part.  I will use these to construct the matching section for a 20m j-pole, where the spread distance is not critical but needs to be relatively stable.  The wires snap in tightly, but if that's not enough, there's a slot for small zip ties at the tip to make it tighter (and parameters to adjust the slot size if needed).

comments.text: Great work.  Since I'm using 25mm, I'm scaling up a bit, by 1.3.  Do you know if that's about right to match other 25mm tiles I have?
comments.author: MarauderX

comments.text: Hey, thank you! Well, the tiles might work as is depending on your models' base size. If you use 25mm bases, scaling up by 125% will make the tiles 25mm. But, if you want true 25mm scale (like, you're using 25mm scale miniatures, not 28mm scale that are on 25mm bases?), with the doors and all that, you'll want to scale up by 134%. I just figured this out using Sgt. Scalesby, can't tell you how useful he's been, haha.

Inspired by a turkish tea set I created this 10 way drink dispenser. More of an eye catcher than a time saver but funny and definitely working. Is work in progress, I'm thinking about switchable heads for 6, 8 and 10 persons atm.

Print upside down, resolution doesn't matter fill of 10 should be enought, but I recommend using ReplicatorG with the following changes on your skeinforge profile: Modul Fill:
Diaphragm Thickness (layers): 2
Solid Surface Thickness (layers): 5 With standard settings it may not be fully watherthight, at least Prototype #2 wasn't. Finished product uses about 200g or 70 meters of fillament and took 12,8 hours with sailfish on a Rep2 and feedrate of 120 and 0.2 resolution.

comments.text: is this really food safe?
comments.author: donb

comments.text: PLA as far as I know is food safe (it's made out of food after all) and can even be eaten and digested. However the way it is processed in 3D printing isn't specifically certified, but I'm not worried about that really. The only thing I'm concerned is that printed parts have a very rought surface, bacteria breeding grounds like on a very used cutting board. However you cut raw meat on the last and properl cleaned it isn't unsafe either.
comments.author: donb

comments.text: uncolored PLA is generally considered food safe. If you have any kind of colored PLA, you'd need to consult with the place that added the dye.

This thing is created from Bosch's 3dwarehouse catalog. I simply converted the .skp file into .stl format. Here below the link:
https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model.html?id=u25b18a9e-2b94-4fbf-abd9-d4b85ff9f707

UPDATE: The site has been moved to: http://nasa3d.arc.nasa.gov/ In honor of Space Month, and for those who may be waxing nostalgic about the last shuttle flight, I wanted to share a NASA website I found with free 3D model files of numerous spacecraft: http://www.nasa.gov/multimedia/3d_resources/models.html Several examples are attached. They are in 3ds format, which I was able to import to Google sketch, but I have not been able to export them to an stl file yet. If someone is able to do this, please post the procedure for us challenged newbies. Thank you.

title: Flashforge Creator Pro X Spool Holder

description.text:
A smaller spool holder for the Creator Pro X. The default ones are huge and don't fit custom filament. This prints without rafts or support, in two separate pieces.

Print the Left and Right separately and they snap perfectly into the FlashForge in the back. I even have printed with only one half in, while the other half finished printing.

description.text:
Version V.2.1g (2.7mm - 3.00mm)

  1. Knob for OLED
  2. Spare - C holder for effector x 2
  3. Spare - Platform

Version V.2.1f

  1. Gap adjust to 2.7mm
  2. Acrylic Extruder （MK7 Drive Gear-12MM, 40 teeth, 5mm inner + 623zz )
  3. Z position screw added to left hand side.
  4. MKS OLED 0.96 inch & 1.3 inch with marlin firmware uploaded

Version V.2.1b

  1. Extruder moved in, make Tiny Boy more Tiny.
  2. Move Z end stop adjustment to the back.
  3. Z position screw changed.

Version V2.1a

  1. Ventilation windows for X and Z stepper (corrected Z window)
  2. M6 rod for Z axis (more stable)
  3. Hexagon back
  4. Spare Platform (damaged the home corner by hotend last time)
  5. 12v DC power female plug (corrected)
  6. Trapezoid leg
  7. Spool bearing

Tinyboy BOM:
Lasercut Acrylic x 1

bearing 603zz x 6
bearing LM4UU x 12

Phillips Head M2.5 5mm x 10 for step motor
Phillips Head M2 8mm x 6 for end stop
Phillips Head M3 5mm x 16
Hex Screw M3 10mm x 15
Hex Screw M3 12mm x 17
Hex Screw M3 16mm x 5
Hex Screw M3 22mm x 4
Screw shaft M6 180mm x 1
M6 nut x 1 Square size
M3 nut x 17
M3 brass stud 6mm x 6
M3 washer 70.5 x 20
M3 washer 90.8( for belt bearing) x 6

Rod 4mm 130mm x 2
Rod 4mm 140mm x 2
Rod 4mm180mm x 2

fastener 2.5mm x 22

stepper_28 x 3
stepper_42(For Extruder) x 1
pulley MXL 16T x 2
Coupling 5mm x 6mm x 1

Timing Belts MXL - 4mm x 1M (Y Axis 43cm, X Axis 47cm)

mega2560 ramps1.4 with 4 A4988 stepstick x 1
Micro switch (for endstop) x 3
Metal Extruder (mk8) x 1
e3dv6 x 1
PTFE OD 4mm ID 2mm L 80cm x 1
12V 6A Transformer x 1

description.text:
Makerbot´s Replicator Desktop has it´s filament spool holder enclosed within the machine which is nice. Due to this only a special spool will fit. And so, if you want to use another spool your options are somewhat limited.
This Spool holder mounts on the back of the existing spool holder once it´s in it´s loading position.

Pull the filament tube so that the end of the tube is on the back of the machine enabling the filament to enter the tube from the back.

Please also see our Universal Cantilevered Spool Holder for 3D printers

remixed_from.author: bgkdavis
remixed_from.title: Delta Printer Filament holder Mk2 100% poly

title: Delta Printer Filament holder Mk3 99.5% poly, Adaptable Spigot

description.text:
Looking back over the development of this device I feel I may have become a little guilty of taking a simple concept and making it complicated, but with good intentions.

This design has been 100% built and tested, and whilst I call this the Mk3 design, I've actually made and rejected about 6 other design iterations that haven't made it to public viewing.

Each released iteration of this design I feel has some merit and maybe drawbacks ,the first benefits from its pure simplicity and is very strong, the second benefits from being made without need for any hardware, and this version....?

I suggest to those interested, that rather than just opt for the latest and greatest option, you consider the original or Mk2 as viable alternatives... maybe even remix elements of the three designs to make something that better suits your needs.

What I've added to this version is a spring loaded universal spigot that is adaptable to any size central hole, the first two versions solved this problem by using the spigot inserts, and if you rarely change your brand of filament then this is simple and great, but each time you try new filament you may need to first make a new spigot adapter.

This design does require a little hardware for the spigot assembly, namely 2 elastic bands and 3 10mm M3 countersunk screws, hence the loss of its 100% poly rating.

With this iteration I think there is still room for improvement and I offer the challenge to improve it to others, Whilst I would particularly like to get rid of the screws and the elastic bands my attempts at doing this yielded poor results, maybe find a better way of setting the spool in place, or making the assembly a little easier, there is a lot of scope where an imaginative builder can effect improvements, but for myself I feel its time to move back to my other projects.

BTW apologies for the poor videos, they are there to try and help, but you may enjoy them for their comedic value.... pity they don't do Oscars for best movie where the camera falls over.

https://youtu.be/V1y7jMeg4qU
https://youtu.be/bnAwEl8AEoA

There are a total of 19 printed parts in this build, 12 rollers, 3 arms and the 4 disc parts, all are printable without support.

0.2mm print height is recommended, particularly on the main discs with clips or bearing surfaces. all parts on my prototype were printed in PLA on a RRP Mendel 3 with a 0.5mm nozzzle

If a higher load capacity is needed you can make this without a spacer plate, just print a lot more rollers and fill the race with them.

When printing the rollers its best to print them with the large end on the bed.

Its best to assemble this from the top down clip the cam plate to the top race with the arms between them and the pins in the outter slots, this may be a little tricky, but take care to not break the clips, it may help to use the blade of an exacto knife to carefully lever the clips open.

Next insert three M3 countersink screws, making sure that the arms can move freely and the screws don't protrude from the bottom of the top race.

The screws should self tap into the plastic, but may benefit from running a 2.5mm drill through the top race holes and a 3mm drill through the arm holes, if you haev a M3 tap then use this but its not essential.

Next attach three elastic bands and check that the arms spring outwards and when you pinch a pair of levers at the edge the arms should contract, try fitting it to a filament spool.

Before assembling the races first check that the rollers will roll free in each of the races, if there are any bumps of irregularities trim with an exacto knife.

title: outlet cover/adapter for camper 12V to USB

description.text:
I bought an adapter to charge my usb devices in my camper. I looked for a place where to install it and decided to replace a standard 12 V socket.
Now I needed a new cover to make things fit together. Luckily I had a new 3D-Printer ans so I made one of my first 3D-designs with freecad.
I added the tube in the center, because the space behind the cover was not deep enough for the installation. The ring on the backside gives stability to the cover plate.

Needs support underneeth.
I added the freecad files, so you can customize it.

This is the converter I bought - others work as well!
http://www.amazon.de/Dual-USB-Zigarettenanz%C3%BCnder-Adapter-Handy-Deckel/dp/B00JFTAJ4E/ref=pd_bia_nav_t_1?ie=UTF8&refRID=1CBKNZ2WXKDWJ64Y67CV

author: willie42

title: The ugliest happy and sad pendant

description.text:
I know, I know. This is for sure the ugliest thing I've ever made. Anyway, here it is...
Just a simple pendant with reversible faces. You can pass a cord through its ears and wear its happy face or its sad face according to your feelings, they are even stackable, just press-in one in top of the other. Or you can create a string of lots of happys or sads. You can even use it as a marker, if it smiles work done, otherwise pending. Or even to count positive or negative points, you decide. I have put a little hole into the eyes to be black painted with a sharpie and give it a cool appearance, feel free to paint its eyebrows, moustache, beard, makeup or hair and customize as you want, I kept it simple for that reason.

Freecad sources included as usual, in case you want to modify/add something. Just let me know.

Happy stringing!!

author: magonegro

description.text:
Greetings! Got your hands on one of the Raspberry Pi Foundation's new 7" touchscreen display modules? Need something to prop it up when you're using it in on your desk or in your project?

The Raspberry Pi Guy has got you covered! I have designed a slip-in stand for the display - simply print it out on your 3D printer and place the bottom of your display into the slot. The Raspberry-Pi-logo shaped stand will keep your touchscreen display up securely and safely, with plenty of clearance on the back for other add ons and HATs.

See it in action in my release video! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k7byf2h_bT8

NOTE: the Raspberry Pi logo is a trademark of the Raspberry Pi Foundation. I would like to thank them for their generosity in letting me use it for this display stand. You can read more about their trademark rules here: https://www.raspberrypi.org/trademark-rules/

I printed my display stand in blood red PLA on an Ultimaker 2 with the following settings:

Layer Height: 0.1mm
Shell Thickness: 0.8mm
Print Speed: 50mm/s
Travel Speed: 150mm/s
Infill Density: 18%
Cooling Fans: Enabled

This prints without the need for any supports and on my Ultimaker 2 took around 4/5 hours to do so.

Is your display the wrong orientation for the stand? Try this helpful suggestion from "fredmon3":

In /boot/config.txt you can add a line that says:

lcd_rotate=2

Using 'display_rotate' won't also rotate the touches detected on the screen to match so be sure to use "lcd_rotate".

comments.text: Printed like a charm.  Sized to fit on my small volume M3D.  Thanks.

description.text: unlike other spool holders which hold the spools upright side by side, this spool holder holds them lying down and are stacked upon one another, the intelligent roller design allows for free spin of any spool as it is pulled by the printer. (pictures coming soon when I print it myself)

The base needs to be printed twice
9 bearings need to be printed
three centre roller hub
three large rollers
one middle hub

using sections of PVC pipe with an outer diameter of about 20mm (0.78 inches) the three centre roller hubs can be connected to the middle hub, using a screw a long piece of PVC pipe (as tall as needed to hold your spools) can be held in the base, the middle hub with roller assemblies attached slides over the centre pipe then another base sits on top of that. spools of filament may then sit on top of that to your desire.

comments.text: So far I have only tested the weight capacity with three full spools of filament (3kg of weight) for a shot period of time, however i estimate that it could probably handle half a dozen.

Made at Fab Lab Aachen!

When my friend Heike Krier got out an old Swatch, a present from her mom, its watch strap fell apart. Using a model by laird as a starting point, we used OpenSCAD and a Dremel3D20 printer with TPC FLEX 45 flexible filament to print her a new watch strap. The metal pins, transparent clasp and safety hold are still original, although the model contains a spare hold.

This will fit Swatch watches with a 17mm wide watch strap (measured at the watch case, right beneath the pin tube), with two cutouts in the pin tube at the watch case. See http://www.watchpapst.de/de/seelsorge/armband-auswahl.html for how to measure your Swatch strap width. We spent a lot of time getting the shapes just right, to fit the watch perfectly just like the original strap.

You can print the STL file directly, or open the OpenSCAD file and change the length of the tongue and buckle bands to your needs by just editing two numbers in the file. Changing width or thickness of the strap will require some manual fixes to the pin tubes, but should not be necessary for Swatch straps.

On the Dremel3d20 printer, we used the "high precision and low speed" setting to print the flexible filament successfully.

The hardest part is getting the metal buckle pin out that attaches the strap to the plastic buckle. Hint: Unlike the metal pins attaching the straps to the watch case, you can't push this one out sideways. :) Instead, after removing the old buckle strap from the watch, put the buckle strap into a vise so the metal buckle pin sits horizontally 3 mm above the vise surface. Then you can pull/bend the plastic buckle over the metal buckle pin with your fingers to remove it. Use the same technique to insert the metal buckle pin with the new strap back into the plastic buckle.

comments.text: Nice refinement! The shaping really makes the band look great!

description.text:
FilamentChallenge - Easy Spool Holder

Simple to print
Simple to change
Easy to use

Parts that are not printed:
Ball bearings
M8 threaded rod
3mm screws

To get the proper length spacer, use the customizer, but read the instruction first.

It is all based on a 8mm threaded rod

Fixed parameters are:
End Caps: 10mm (times 2)
Washers: 3mm (times 4)

Recommended bearings 8x16x5 mm
I recommend that the width between the spacers (bearing width on one side) is a minimum of 10mm.

You can find all formulas and "calculator" in the attached Excel file.

The Excel "Calculator can also calculate a "multi-width" setup.
The idea is to make a roller that can take different spools with different widths.
Key in the narrowest spool and the widest spool and it will calculate the spacer width, threaded rod length, number of bearings extra to use and so on.

Calculations:
Spacer is calculated as follows, Spacer_width=(Spool_width+2)-(Number_of_bearingsBearing_width)-(2Washer)

Calculate the length of the threaded rod using the following, rod_length=(2End_caps)+(4Washers)+(Number_of_bearings*Bearing_width)+Spacer_width-1
